choices.text: Get consent from mother for P/V

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl presents to you with her mother, reporting abdominal discomfort and is found to be 12 weeks pregnant based on a positive urine pregnancy test. As a medical professional, what would be your initial course of action? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Inform Police

 

Explanation

 

In many jurisdictions, pregnancy in a minor may be considered evidence of statutory rape or sexual abuse, hence, informing the police is crucial for legal proceedings and safeguarding the minor.

 

Other Option

 

Option A. Start examining: Although a medical examination is necessary, it must be conducted with proper legal and parental consent, especially considering the age and the situation's sensitivity.

 

Option C. Preserve clothing: This could be necessary in a case where forensic evidence needs to be gathered, especially if there was recent assault. However, this would follow legal reporting.

 

Option D. Take consent from mother: Consent is crucial, especially for minors. However, it does not preclude the obligation to report statutory rape or sexual abuse to authorities.

 

Educational objective :

 

  • When dealing with potentially criminal situations involving minors, such as a young teenager's pregnancy, the first step is to ensure the situation is addressed legally and safely. 
  • Informing law enforcement and ensuring proper medical and legal procedures safeguard the minor's health and legal rights.

choices.text: It typically follows an episode of hemorrhagic colitis
Fever is usually mild or absent
Serotonin plays no role in its pathogenesis

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS) is the least accurate? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The condition is often self-limiting

 

HUS is a serious form of thrombotic microangiopathy (TMA) characterized by endothelial cell injury, platelet and hyaline thrombi formation, and resultant organ damage. The evidence indicates HUS requires specific therapeutic interventions based on its variant type, with significant potential for morbidity and mortality, particularly related to acute kidney injury. This contradicts the notion that it's typically self-limiting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It typically follows an episode of hemorrhagic colitis: This is accurate for STEC HUS (also known as D+ HUS), where diarrhea, often bloody, precedes microangiopathic hemolytic anemia within 1 week in >80% of cases. This gastrointestinal prodrome is characteristic of Shiga toxin-producing E. coli infection.

 

Option C. Fever is usually mild or absent: This statement is correct. The clinical presentation typically includes abdominal pain, cramping, and vomiting, while fever is notably absent in most cases of classic HUS.

 

Option D. Serotonin plays no role in its pathogenesis: The pathogenesis of HUS involves Shiga toxins binding to glycolipid receptors (Gb3) on renal microvascular cells, triggering inflammatory cascades with cytokines and chemokine receptors that result in microvascular thrombosis. Serotonin is not implicated in this pathogenic pathway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HUS represents a serious disease process requiring variant-specific management approaches, with treatment potentially including supportive care, antimicrobial considerations, plasma therapies, or complement inhibition depending on the subtype.

questions.text: In which of the following locations does meiosis normally occur in the human body? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Adult ovary

 

Meiosis occurs in the adult ovary.

 

  • Meiosis is the process by which gametes (sperm and eggs) are produced in sexually reproducing organisms.
  • It occurs only in germ cells and leads to the formation of haploid gametes.
  • To reduce the number of chromosomes to the haploid number of 23, meiosis requires two cell divisions, meiosis I and meiosis II.
  • In females, meiosis occurs in the ovaries during fetal development, but is arrested in prophase I until puberty.
  • After puberty, meiosis resumes and one ovum is produced each month.
  • In males, meiosis occurs in the testes and produces sperm.
  • Meiosis in the testes begins during puberty and continues throughout adulthood.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adrenal: The adrenal glands are located atop each kidney and are involved in the production of various hormones, such as cortisol, aldosterone, and sex steroids. Meiosis, the process by which germ cells divide to produce gametes with half the number of chromosomes, does not occur in the adrenal glands. Instead, the adrenal glands are involved in steroidogenesis or the production of steroid hormones.

 

Option C. Prepubertal testis: The testes are the male reproductive organs that produce spermatozoa (sperm cells) and testosterone. In males, meiosis begins during puberty. In the prepubertal testis, the germ cells are not yet undergoing meiosis to form mature sperm cells. These germ cells (spermatogonia) proliferate by mitosis during childhood but only enter meiosis to become spermatocytes and eventually mature spermatozoa after the onset of puberty.

 

Option D. Hypothalamus: It is a region of the brain responsible for various vital functions, including the release of hormones that regulate the pituitary gland. It is not involved in meiosis. Instead, it plays an essential role in regulating various physiological processes, such as body temperature, thirst, hunger, and circadian rhythms. It also plays a significant role in controlling the release of hormones from the anterior pituitary by producing releasing or inhibiting hormones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adult ovaries are responsible for producing ova (egg cells) and hormones such as estrogen and progesterone. Meiosis begins in the fetal ovaries but is arrested in prophase I until puberty.

 

After puberty, with each menstrual cycle, some oocytes resume meiosis, completing meiosis I and arresting in meiosis II. It's only after fertilization that meiosis II completes. Therefore, meiosis occurs in the adult ovary as it is essential for the formation of mature ova or egg cells.

questions.text: A female patient presents with complaints of thick white vaginal secretions. Which of the following can be used to identify the likely species of the causative agent? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CHROMagar

 

The clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of candidiasis. CHROMagar can be used for the rapid identification of Candida species. It is based on the fungal enzymatic action on various chromogenic substrates in the medium.

 

After incubation on CHROMagar for 1-4 days, colonies are seen: Candida albicans colonies appear green.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bird seed agar: Mainly used for the isolation and differentiation of Cryptococcus neoformans due to its ability to produce brown colonies owing to phenol oxidase activity.

 

Option B. Brain heart infusion agar: A rich, non-selective medium used for cultivating a variety of fastidious organisms, not specific for differentiating Candida species.

 

Option D. Sabouraud dextrose agar: Commonly used for the culture of fungi but does not differentiate between Candida species as effectively as CHROMagar.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CHROMagar is the preferred medium for rapidly identifying and differentiating various Candida species directly from clinical specimens like vaginal swabs, with Candida albicans typically forming green colonies on this medium. This tool is essential for quick, accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment of candidiasis.

questions.text: A small child was playing with her maid where she rotated her by holding from arms. Immediately after, the child started crying. On examination, her forearm was pronated. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pulled elbow

 

  • History of traction on elbow with forearm pronated is classical of pulled elbow.

 

PULLED ELBOW/NURSE MAID’S ELBOW

 

  • It is subluxation of radial head or more accurately subluxation of the annular (orbicular) ligament which slips up over the head of radius into the radio-capitellar joint.

 

 

  • Mechanism of Injury: Traction to elbow.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Maximum incidence in 1-4 years of age group.
    • The child holds the elbow in slight flexion with the forearm pronated.
    • X-rays are normal.
  • Treatment:
    • Reduced by flexing the elbow to 90° and rapidly and firmly rotating the forearm into full supination on outdoor basis without anaesthesia. 
    • Immobilization is not necessary.
    • Supination is a gravity-assisted movement and pulled elbow may be reduced spontaneously by gravity, but this may take time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dislocation of elbow. Elbow Dislocations in the pediatric population usually occur in older children (10-15 years) and can be associated with elbow fractures such as medial epicondyle fractures. Male: female = 3:1. Very rare in younger children < 3 years old. Mechanism of injury is fall on an outstretched hand. Symptoms include painful and swollen elbow, attempts at motion are painful and restricted. On physical examination, the elbow is held in flexion, forearm appears to be shortened from the anterior and posterior view. On palpation, distal humerus creates a fullness within the antecubital fossa. Radiographs shows loss of radiocapitellar and ulnohumeral relationship but maintained radial and ulnar relationship. Treatment is usually closed reduction and brief immobilization for 1-2 weeks. 

 

 

Option C. Fracture head of radius. Radial head fractures are common injuries and may occur in association with dislocation of the elbow. In children, radial neck fractures are more common than radial head fractures. Classically, the head of radius should not be excised in children because it will interfere with the synchronous growth of radius and ulna, producing wrist and elbow deformity. It may lead to proximal radial migration and subluxation of inferior radio-ulnar joint, weakness of extremity and discomfort in distal radioulnar joint with heavy activities, and may produce cubitus valgus deformity.

 

 

Option D. Fracture coronoid process. Coronoid Fractures are traumatic elbow fractures that are generally pathognomonic for an episode of elbow instability. The patient presents with elbow deformity & swelling, elbow/forearm/wrist pain. On inspection & palpation, there is varus or valgus deformity, ecchymosis & swelling, and diffuse tenderness. The treatment involves brief immobilization, followed by early range of motion. 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

History of traction on elbow with forearm in pronation in a child < 4 years of age is a classical feature of pulled elbow.

questions.text: The occurrence of hyperthyroidism following the administration of supplemental iodine to individuals with endemic iodine deficiency goiter is known as: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Jod-Basedow effect

 

The Jod-Basedow effect refers to hyperthyroidism that occurs when individuals with preexisting thyroid disease (particularly those with endemic iodine deficiency goiter) receive supplemental iodine. In patients with long-standing iodine deficiency, the thyroid glands develop autonomous nodules that produce excess thyroid hormone when suddenly exposed to iodine supplementation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wolff-Chaikoff Effect: This is the transient inhibition of thyroid hormone synthesis that occurs in response to high iodine intake. In normal glands, this effect is temporary (9-10 days) as the thyroid "escapes" from this inhibition. It causes hypothyroidism, not hyperthyroidism.

 

Option C. Pendred's syndrome: This is a genetic disorder characterized by congenital sensorineural hearing loss and goiter. It's not related to iodine administration causing hyperthyroidism.

 

Option D. De Quervain's thyroiditis: This is another name for subacute granulomatous thyroiditis, which is a painful inflammatory condition of the thyroid, typically following a viral infection. It's not directly related to iodine administration.

 

Educational Objective: The Jod-Basedow effect represents paradoxical hyperthyroidism following iodine administration in patients with preexisting iodine deficiency, as their thyroid glands have adapted to produce hormones even with minimal iodine availability.

questions.text: A 12 weeks pregnant lady visited the doctor. On ultrasound, it was found she has a low-lying placenta. What is the next best step? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Repeat ultrasound at 32 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

At 12 weeks gestation, the presence of a low-lying placenta is often not a cause for immediate concern because the placenta typically "migrates" upward as the pregnancy progresses. This migration is due to the expansion of the uterus, which effectively moves the placenta away from the cervix. Therefore, the recommended management is to repeat an ultrasound between 28 to 32 weeks to reassess the position of the placenta. By this time, the majority of placentas that were initially low-lying will have moved to a safer position, allowing for a more accurate determination of whether there will be any complications related to placenta previa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The next best step for a pregnant woman found to have a low-lying placenta at 12 weeks is to repeat the ultrasound at around 32 weeks to reassess the placenta's position and determine appropriate management.

choices.text: B fibers are more susceptible to pressure than A fibers
A fibers are more sensitive to pressure than C fibers
C fibers are more sensitive to pressure than A fibers
Motor nerves are more affected by sleep than sensory nerves

questions.text: A man falls into a deep sleep with one arm under his head. He finds he is not able to move this arm when he awakens. However, it tingles and pain sensation in the arm is still intact. What is the reason for the loss of motor function without loss of pain sensation is that in the nerves to his arm?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. A fibers are more sensitive to pressure than C fibers

 

Explanation  

 

The reason for the loss of motor function without loss of pain sensation is that in the nerves to his arm, A-fibers are more sensitive to pressure than C fibers.

 

 

Pressure on a nerve due to sleeping with arms under the head leads to the loss of conduction in large-diameter motor, touch, and pressure fibers, while pain sensation remains relatively intact.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. B fibers are more susceptible to pressure than A fibers: Incorrect. B fibers, which are generally involved in autonomic functions, are not the primary concern in this scenario involving motor and sensory disturbances.

 

Option C. C fibers are more sensitive to pressure than A fibers: Incorrect. It's the opposite; A fibers are more sensitive to pressure than C fibers, making them more likely to be compromised under mechanical compression.

 

Option D. Motor nerves are more affected by sleep than sensory nerves: Incorrect. The loss of function is not due to sleep per se but due to mechanical pressure affecting nerve conduction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In situations where pressure is applied to nerves, such as sleeping with an arm in a compromising position, the larger, myelinated A fibers (including motor fibers) are more susceptible to disruption compared to the smaller, unmyelinated C fibers. This leads to a loss of motor function and normal touch sensation, while pain sensation remains relatively intact due to the resilience of C fibers to mechanical pressure.

 

Relative susceptibility of nerve fibres –

questions.text: All of the following methods are antilarval measures except? [NEET PG 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Malathion

 

  • Malathion is primarily an anti-adult mosquito control measure, not an anti-larval measure. It belongs to the organophosphorus group of insecticides that acts as a nerve/contact poison inhibiting acetylcholinesterase. 
  • While malathion can be used for larval control in specific formulations, it is classified under anti-adult measures in mosquito control strategies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intermittent irrigation: This is an anti-larval measure classified under environmental/physical control methods (source reduction). Intermittent irrigation is a water management technique that prevents mosquito breeding by alternately flooding and drying fields, disrupting the mosquito life cycle.

 

Option B. Paris green: This is an anti-larval measure. Paris green contains copper aceto-arsenite and functions as a stomach poison for mosquito larvae.

 

Option C. Gambusia affinis: This option represents a biological control method specifically targeting mosquito larvae. Gambusia affinis (mosquito fish) are larvivorous fish that feed on mosquito larvae, with particular affinity for Anopheles larvae.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Mosquito control measures are classified as anti-larval or anti-adult based on which life stage they target. Environmental modifications (source reduction), biological control (larvivorous fish), and certain chemical applications (Paris green) target larvae, while residual insecticides like malathion primarily target adult mosquitoes.

questions.text: Which of the following have the most friable vegetations? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Infective endocarditis

 

Explanation: 

 

Infective endocarditis is characterized by large, irregular, often destructive masses that can extend from valve leaflets onto adjacent structures. These vegetations are notably friable (easily crumbled) due to their composition of fibrin, platelets, inflammatory cells, and large numbers of microorganisms. The friable nature of these vegetations makes them prone to fragmentation, leading to septic embolization which can cause infarcts in distant organs. These lesions are typically bulky and destructive compared to other types of vegetative endocarditis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Libman Sack's endocarditis - This is a form of non-bacterial thrombotic endocarditis seen in SLE patients. The vegetations are small to medium-sized and inflammatory but are more organized and less friable than those of infective endocarditis. They can be attached to either side of valve leaflets.

 

Option C. Rheumatic heart disease - In the acute phase, rheumatic heart disease shows small verrucae (vegetations) along the lines of valve closure. These are small (1-2mm), firm, and composed of fibrinoid necrosis and fibrin deposition, making them much less friable than infective endocarditis lesions.

 

Option D. SLE - While SLE can cause Libman-Sacks endocarditis (already addressed above), SLE itself is a systemic autoimmune disease and not a specific type of endocarditis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Infective endocarditis produces the most friable vegetations among the listed options due to their composition and structure, making them prone to fragmentation and embolization.

choices.text: Non-Hodgkin lymphoma
Bronchogenic Carcinoma
Germ cell tumor

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient is diagnosed with pure red cell aplasia and a mediastinal mass. Which of the following can be the likely cause? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thymoma

 

Thymoma is the most likely diagnosis for the clinical presentation of a mediastinal mass with pure red cell aplasia.

 

Pure red cell aplasia (PRCA) is a rare syndrome characterized by a selective failure of erythroid element production in the bone marrow but normal granulopoiesis and megakaryocytopoiesis.

 

The patients have normocytic normochromic anemia, with normal granulocyte and platelet counts. Reticulocytes are significantly reduced or absent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Non-Hodgkin lymphoma:

 

Association: While lymphomas can present as mediastinal masses and may cause cytopenias, they are not specifically associated with pure red cell aplasia.

 

Option C. Bronchogenic Carcinoma:

 

Association: Bronchogenic carcinoma typically presents with respiratory symptoms and does not have a known association with PRCA.

 

Option D. Germ cell tumor:

 

Association: Germ cell tumors can present as mediastinal masses but are not specifically linked to PRCA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thymoma is the most likely cause of a mediastinal mass in a patient with pure red cell aplasia. PRCA is characterized by a selective deficiency of erythroid precursors in the bone marrow, leading to severe anemia with normal granulocyte and platelet counts, and is often associated with thymoma.

questions.text: Anterior ethmoidal sinus drains into: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Middle meatus

 

The anterior ethmoidal sinus, along with the maxillary sinus and frontal sinus, drains into the middle meatus of the nasal cavity. The middle meatus is a crucial drainage pathway for these sinuses, allowing mucus to flow from the sinuses into the nasal cavity. This drainage is essential for maintaining sinus health and preventing infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inferior meatus: This meatus primarily serves as the drainage site for the nasolacrimal duct, not the ethmoidal sinuses.

 

Option C. Superior meatus: The superior meatus is the drainage site for the posterior ethmoidal sinus.

 

Option D. Nasal cavity: This is a general term and does not specify the precise drainage pathway for the anterior ethmoidal sinus, which specifically drains into the middle meatus.

 

Additionally, the sphenoid sinuses drain into the sphenoethmoidal recess.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anterior ethmoidal sinus, along with the maxillary and frontal sinuses, drains into the middle meatus of the nasal cavity.

questions.text: Which of the following agents has blood:gas partition coefficient similar to nitrous oxide? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Desflurane

 

The blood-gas partition coefficient of an inhalational anesthetic agent measures its solubility in blood. Agents with a lower blood-gas partition coefficient, like nitrous oxide, have faster onset and recovery times. Desflurane has a similar low blood-gas partition coefficient to nitrous oxide, resulting in rapid induction and emergence.

 

Blood: Gas Partition Coefficients:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isoflurane: Isoflurane has a higher blood-gas partition coefficient compared to nitrous oxide, indicating slower onset and recovery.

 

Option C. Sevoflurane: Although sevoflurane has a relatively low blood-gas partition coefficient, it is still higher than that of nitrous oxide and desflurane.

 

Option D. Halothane: Halothane has a significantly higher blood-gas partition coefficient, leading to a slower onset and recovery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Desflurane has a blood-gas partition coefficient most similar to that of nitrous oxide, indicative of its relatively low solubility in blood and, consequently, its rapid onset and recovery profile among the volatile anesthetics listed.

choices.text: Aschoff's bodies
Epithelioid granuloma
Granulomatous vasculitis

questions.text: A 34-year-old female patient presented to the outpatient department with migratory arthritis and examination revealed a pan-systolic murmur. An echocardiography was performed which was suggestive of mitral regurgitation. A biopsy specimen was obtained and the image is provided below. What is the most likely lesion shown in the histopathology slide? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aschoff’s bodies

 

Acute rheumatic fever is suggested by the clinical findings of migratory arthritis, pan-systolic murmur, and mitral regurgitation. Aschoff's bodies are the most likely lesion in the histopathological slide.

 

Acute RF causes focal inflammatory lesions in a variety of tissues. Aschoff bodies are distinct lesions in the heart that consist of foci of lymphocytes (primarily T cells), occasional plasma cells, and plump activated macrophages called Anitschkow cells (pathognomonic for RF). These macrophages have a lot of cytoplasm and central round-to-ovoid nuclei with chromatin in a central, slender, wavy ribbon (hence the name "caterpillar cells"), and they can get multinucleated.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Epithelioid granuloma: Epithelioid granulomas are associated with chronic inflammatory conditions such as tuberculosis or sarcoidosis. They do not have the characteristic Anitschkow cells seen in Aschoff bodies.

 

Option  C. Granulomatous vasculitis: Granulomatous vasculitis is characterized by granulomas in the walls of blood vessels, which is seen in conditions like granulomatosis with polyangiitis. It does not match the histological description of Aschoff bodies.

 

Option D. Granuloma inguinale: Granuloma inguinale, caused by Klebsiella granulomatis, presents with genital ulcers and Donovan bodies on histology, which is unrelated to the cardiac findings described here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aschoff bodies, which consist of lymphocytes, plasma cells, and characteristic Anitschkow cells, are the hallmark histological feature of acute rheumatic fever, a condition that can lead to significant cardiac involvement, including mitral regurgitation.

choices.text: Do ultrasound for gestational age, check for abnormalities, check sex, and tell the mother.
Do ultrasound for gestational age, check for abnormalities, check sex but don’t tell the mother.
Do ultrasound for gestational age, check for abnormalities, don’t check the sex.
Don’t do ultrasound, do ANC only.

questions.text: A 28-year-old G5L4 with all 4-girl children presents at 18 weeks and asks for the sex of the child on ultrasound. This is her first antenatal visit. What should be done? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Do ultrasound for gestational age, check for abnormalities, don’t check the sex.


The Ans. is C because, according to the Pre-Conception and Pre-Natal Diagnostic Techniques (PCPNDT) Act, sex determination of the fetus is illegal and punishable by law. At 18 weeks, the primary purpose of the ultrasound is to assess gestational age and check for any fetal abnormalities as part of the anomaly scan. Checking or revealing the sex of the fetus is prohibited and carries legal consequences. Therefore, the healthcare provider should perform the ultrasound for the medical purposes it is intended for and avoid even viewing the sex of the fetus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Do ultrasound for gestational age, check for abnormalities, check sex, and tell the mother: is incorrect because checking the sex and informing the mother is illegal under the PCPNDT Act, and can lead to legal repercussions, including imprisonment.

 

Option B. Do ultrasound for gestational age, check for abnormalities, check sex but don’t tell the mother: is also incorrect. Even looking at the fetus’s sex, regardless of whether it is disclosed, is a violation of the law and is punishable.

 

Option D. Don’t do ultrasound, do ANC only: is incorrect because the ultrasound at 18 weeks is necessary for evaluating gestational age and detecting any fetal abnormalities, which are critical aspects of prenatal care.

 

Educational Objective:


The key point to remember is that checking or revealing the sex of the fetus during an ultrasound is illegal under the PCPNDT Act. The ultrasound should only be used for assessing fetal gestational age and abnormalities.

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown in the image. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bohler Braun splint 

 

  • It is a common splint used in wards for immobilization and reduction of most lower limb fractures and treatment of other lower limb pathologies.
  • Structure:
    • It consists of an iron frame with a set of 4 pulleys for application of mobile traction. 
    • It is modified from Braun splint which consists of only 1 pulley for distal tibia or calcaneal skeletal traction. 
    • Bohler’s Modification was addition of 2 more pulleys for proximal tibia and distal femur traction.
  • Uses of 4 pulleys:
    • Lowermost pulley is used for tibia and fibular injuries
    • Second from bottom is used for supracondylar fracture femur
    • 3rd (directed away from patient) is used for fracture shaft femur middle third
    • 4th (topmost and directed towards the patient) is used to prevent foot drop
  • Uses:
    • With traction:
      • For lower limb injuries with displacement/fragment overlap. 
      • The skeletal traction is given via a K wire, Steinman pin, Bohler's pin, etc.
      • In leg fracture, pin goes through calcaneal tuberosity
      • In femur fracture, pin goes through tibial tuberosity in adults, and just above the condyles in children
    • Without traction:
      • Compound fracture with no overlap – for dressing and wound care, and possible immobilization
      • Soft tissue injury to leg
      • In case of cellulitis, gangrene, amputation, etc.
  • Advantages:
    • Mobile traction – especially useful in cases where transportation is necessary as the traction unit is self-contained
    • Places the limb in comfortable position
    • Wound care is possible
    • Multipurpose application
    • Angle of traction can be changed by changing the pulleys without changing the arrangement 
    • Simultaneous traction through Calcaneal/distal tibia and proximal tibia/distal femur can be given
  • Disadvantages & complications:
    • Non-ambulatory
    • Stiffness/contracture
    • Urination and defecation becomes difficult
    • Common peroneal nerve compression
    • Other complications of recumbancy like bed sore, hypostatic pneumonia etc.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thomas splint: The Thomas' splint aims to immobilise the limb and consists of a padded metal ring (either continuous or with an opening, and a strap and buckle on the lateral side) covered with soft leather, attached to an angled bar that extends down the length and both sides of the leg. The bar is usually angled over the hip at the greater trochanter and the two side bars join in a “W” shape at the foot. The ring is available in different sizes to enable it to fit appropriately around the patients' groin (over the ischial tuberosity) and across the gluteal fold. This enables the splint to fit the patient as closely as possible. 

 

 

Option B. Volkmann splint: The Volkmann splint, also known as the Volkmann's turnbuckle splint, is a specialized orthopedic device used to treat Volkmann's contracture. Volkmann's Contracture is a condition that occurs when there is a lack of blood flow to the muscles of the forearm, leading to permanent shortening and tightening of the muscles, resulting in a claw-like deformity of the hand. The Volkmann splint is designed to gradually stretch and lengthen the shortened muscles. It works on a 3-point fixation mechanism and has a turnbuckle that controls and adjusts the tension.

 

 

Option D. Cramer wire: The Cramer splint is a simple but effective medical device that is used to fix fractures. Structurally, it is a reusable medical part in the form of a narrow ladder made of steel or aluminium wire, the flexible elements of which are soldered together. It can be given any shape, anatomically following the contours of the injured limb. It is used for fractures of the lower and upper extremities – shoulder, forearm, hip, ankle, ankles and fingers. In addition, it is used for reliable fixation of the patient’s upper spinal column and head. Immobilization of injured limb using a Cramer splint reduces the level of pain and prevent from additional damage during transportation of the patient.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows the Bohler-Braun splint which is used in the immobilization of the lower limb fractures. 
  • The splint consists of a system of pulleys to provide traction and allow for fracture healing.

questions.text: What is the structure marked with black arrow in the given image: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1st pharyngeal arch

 

Explanation:

 

The marked structure in the image is identified as the malleus.

 

The first pharyngeal arch, also known as the mandibular arch, is responsible for the formation of several structures in the head and neck region.

 

  1. Malleus and Incus Formation: The 1st pharyngeal arch is crucial in forming the malleus and incus, two of the three auditory ossicles in the middle ear. The cartilage component of this arch, known as Meckel's cartilage, gives rise to these ossicles.
  2. Other Structures from the 1st Pharyngeal Arch: Apart from the malleus and incus, the 1st pharyngeal arch also contributes to the formation of the maxilla, mandible, sphenomandibular ligament, and parts of the middle ear, including the anterior malleolar ligament.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 2nd pharyngeal arch: This is incorrect. The 2nd pharyngeal arch (hyoid arch) primarily forms the stapes (another auditory ossicle), styloid process, stylohyoid ligament, and parts of the hyoid bone.

 

Option C. 3rd pharyngeal arch: This is incorrect. The 3rd pharyngeal arch contributes to the formation of the greater horn and lower part of the hyoid bone.

 

Option D. neuroectoderm: This is incorrect in the context of the malleus. While neural crest cells, derived from neuroectoderm, play a significant role in the development of many craniofacial structures, the malleus specifically develops from the 1st pharyngeal arch.

 

Educational Objective:

 

1st arch cartilage: Meckle’s cartilage → 5 ‘M’

 

1. Malleus & Incus

2. Malleolar (Anterior) ligament

3. Spheno-Mandibular ligament

4. Mandible

5. Maxilla

 

2nd arch cartilage: Reichert cartilage → 5 ‘S’

 

1. Stapes (except footplate & Otic capsule)

2. Styloid process

3. Stylohyoid ligament

4. Smaller cornu of hyoid

5. Superior ½ of body of the hyoid

 

3rd arch cartilage:

 

1. Greater cornu of hyoid

2. Inferior ½ of hyoid

 

4th & 6th arch cartilage:

 

-  Laryngeal cartilage

questions.text: Following intravenous administration of noradrenaline, a decrease in heart rate is observed. What is the physiological mechanism responsible for this effect? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Baroreceptor activation

 

Explanation:

 

When noradrenaline is administered intravenously, it primarily stimulates alpha-1 receptors in blood vessels, causing vasoconstriction. This vasoconstriction leads to an increase in diastolic blood pressure and mean arterial pressure. Our body has compensatory mechanisms to maintain homeostasis. When blood pressure increases, baroreceptors located in the blood vessels (particularly in the carotid sinus and aortic arch) detect this change.

 

These baroreceptors sense the elevated blood pressure and become activated. Once activated, they send signals to the central nervous system, specifically stimulating the parasympathetic nervous system. The parasympathetic activation results in the release of acetylcholine, which acts on the heart to slow the heart rate (bradycardia). This is a reflex mechanism known as the baroreceptor reflex or baroreflex.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Stimulation of alpha-1 receptors: This is incorrect because. While noradrenaline does stimulate alpha-1 receptors (causing vasoconstriction and increased blood pressure), the direct effect of alpha-1 stimulation does not cause a decrease in heart rate. Alpha-1 receptors are primarily located on blood vessels, not on the heart. The decrease in heart rate is an indirect effect mediated through the baroreceptor reflex.

 

Option C. Activation of beta-1 receptors: This is incorrect because. Activation of beta-1 receptors would increase heart rate (tachycardia), not decrease it. Beta-1 receptors are present in the heart, and their stimulation leads to positive chronotropic (increased heart rate) and inotropic (increased contractility) effects. While noradrenaline does have some beta-1 agonist activity, the reflex bradycardia from baroreceptor activation usually overrides this direct effect.

 

Option D. Inhibition of baroreceptors: This is incorrect because. Noradrenaline causes activation, not inhibition, of baroreceptors. When baroreceptors are inhibited, they would fail to detect the increase in blood pressure, which would cause a failure of the compensatory mechanism that decreases heart rate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IV administration of noradrenaline causes reflex bradycardia through baroreceptor activation, which is a physiological compensatory mechanism in response to the drug-induced increase in blood pressure.

 

Effect of IV administration of NA on heart rate

questions.text: Which of the following drugs, when given with erythromycin, can cause QT prolongation and Torsades de pointes? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Astemizole

 

Astemizole is an antihistamine that, when combined with enzyme inhibitors such as erythromycin, can lead to QT prolongation. This prolongation of the QT interval on an electrocardiogram can predispose a person to a dangerous arrhythmia known as Torsades de pointes, which can be potentially life-threatening. Astemizole was withdrawn from many markets due to this severe adverse effect when used in combination with other drugs that inhibit its metabolism.

 

Drugs causing QT prolongation if given with erythromycin:

 

  • Cisapride
  • Astemizole
  • Terfinadine

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cetirizine: This is a second-generation antihistamine that does not have significant interactions leading to QT prolongation or Torsades de pointes when combined with erythromycin.

 

Option C. Loratadine: Similar to Cetirizine, Loratadine is another second-generation antihistamine with a better safety profile in terms of cardiac effects. It does not cause QT prolongation or Torsades de pointes in conjunction with erythromycin.

 

Option D. Promethazine: Although promethazine is an older antihistamine that can have sedative effects, it does not have a strong association with QT prolongation or Torsades de pointes when used with erythromycin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Astemizole is a drug that, when taken with erythromycin, can lead to QT prolongation and the serious arrhythmia known as Torsades de pointes. This significant adverse effect led to the withdrawal of Astemizole from the market in many countries.

questions.text: Indomethacin should not be given with ACE inhibitors because: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hyperkalemia

 

Explanation:

 

ACE inhibitors work by inhibiting the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). Aldosterone normally promotes potassium excretion in the distal tubule. When ACE inhibitors block this pathway, aldosterone levels decrease, resulting in reduced potassium excretion and a tendency toward hyperkalemia.

 

NSAIDs like indomethacin further increase this risk through several mechanisms:

 

  • They reduce renal blood flow by inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis
  • They decrease glomerular filtration rate (GFR)
  • They impair renin release
  • They directly interfere with potassium excretion

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyponatremia: While ACE inhibitors can occasionally cause hyponatremia by increasing water retention through ADH mechanisms, this is not significantly worsened by the addition of NSAIDs. The primary concern when combining these drug classes is hyperkalemia.

 

Option C. Hyperuricemia: Although both ACE inhibitors and NSAIDs can independently affect uric acid levels (NSAIDs can increase uric acid levels by decreasing its excretion), hyperuricemia is not the primary concern when combining these medications. The risk of hyperkalemia is more significant and potentially more dangerous.

 

Option D. It may cause severe hypotension: While both ACE inhibitors and NSAIDs can affect blood pressure, their combined effect typically results in a reduction of the antihypertensive efficacy of ACE inhibitors rather than severe hypotension. NSAIDs tend to increase blood pressure by inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis, which opposes the blood pressure-lowering effects of ACE inhibitors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NSAIDs like indomethacin should not be given with ACE inhibitors due to increased risk of hyperkalemia, as both drug classes can interfere with potassium excretion through different mechanisms.

questions.text: All of the following half-lives and radioisotopes are correctly matched, except: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Technetium-99m - 6 days

 

Explanation: 

 

Technetium-99m has a half-life of 6 hours, not 6 days as incorrectly stated in option D. Tc-99m is a metastable nuclear isomer that loses roughly half of its radioactivity in that 6-hour timeframe. This short half-life makes it particularly useful for diagnostic nuclear medicine procedures since it decays quickly after imaging is complete, minimizing radiation exposure to patients.

 

Other Options:

  • Option A: Tritium - 12 years - While tritium is a radioactive isotope of hydrogen
  • Option B: Cobalt - 5.26 years - The half-life for cobalt isn't clearly detailed in the nuclear medicine chapters.
  • Option C: Iodine 131 - 8 days - This is correct as listed in the physical half-lives of commonly used radioisotopes. Iodine-131 is used in thyroid studies and has an 8-day half-life.

 

Other relevant half-lives in nuclear medicine include:

  • Iodine-123: 13.2 hours
  • Gallium-67: 3.3 days
  • Indium-111: 2.8 days
  • Thallium-201: 73 hours

 

Educational Objective:

 

Technetium-99m is the most widely used radioisotope in nuclear medicine with a short half-life of only 6 hours, making it ideal for diagnostic imaging while minimizing patient radiation exposure.

choices.text: Parasympathetic - bladder dysfunction and retrograde ejaculation.
Sympathetic - retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction.
Sympathetic - Impotence and loss of cutaneous sensation in perineal region

questions.text: Identify the most common neurological complication following ligation of the Inferior mesenteric artery during abdominoperineal resection for rectal carcinoma? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sympathetic - retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction.

 

  • An abdominoperineal resection involves the removal of the left colon, pelvic floor, rectum, and anal canal.
  •  It is typically indicated for patients with operable low rectal carcinomas located within 5 cm of the anal verge.
  • The sympathetic innervation of the rectum originates from L1 – L3 spinal nerves, which form the superior hypogastric plexus.  
  • At the level of the sacral promontory, these nerves divide into the left and right hypogastric nerves, traveling on both sides of the pelvis.
  • These nerves supply the rectum and send branches to supply the genitourinary system anteriorly.
  • During pelvic surgeries, it is crucial to be aware of these nerves to avoid injuring them.
  • High ligation of the inferior mesenteric artery (IMA) near the sacral promontory may injure the superior hypogastric nerves, leading to sympathetic dysfunction.
  • This dysfunction is characterized by retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Parasympathetic - bladder dysfunction and retrograde ejaculation: Parasympathetic nerves are less likely to be affected by the ligation of the IMA as their pathways are different. Parasympathetic innervation primarily involves the pelvic splanchnic nerves (S2-S4), which are not typically disrupted in this procedure.

 

Option B. Sympathetic - bladder dysfunction and impotence: While bladder dysfunction is a possible consequence of sympathetic nerve damage, impotence is not the most common result of injury to the sympathetic nerves. The more typical outcome includes retrograde ejaculation.

 

Option D. Sympathetic - Impotence and loss of cutaneous sensation in perineal region: Loss of cutaneous sensation in the perineal region would more likely result from damage to the pudendal nerve, not the sympathetic nerves. Impotence can occur but is less specific compared to retrograde ejaculation in the context of IMA ligation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • During abdominoperineal resection for rectal carcinoma, ligation of the inferior mesenteric artery may lead to sympathetic nerve damage, particularly the superior hypogastric plexus.
  • This can result in neurological complications such as retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction.

questions.text: Name the drug that acts on both the marked points: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Omapatrilat

 

Omapatrilat is a inhibits both neprilysin and Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE). As a result, there is a decrease in Angiotensin II and increase in natriuretic peptide levels, promoting natriuresis, diuresis, vasodilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sacubitril: Sacubitril inhibits neprilysin reducing breakdown of vasoactive peptides such as natriuretic peptides and bradykinin, therefore increasing their levels leading to vasodilation, diuresis, and counteracting the effects of RAAS. Sacubitril is combined with an ARB, valsartan is indicated for the treatment of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF).

 

Option C. Losartan: Losartan is classified under angiotensin receptor blocker, used in the treatment of hypertension. A/E are Hyperkalemia, Dysgeusia, Postural hypotension. C/I in pregnancy, B/L Renal Artery Stenosis. Losartan decreases serum uric acid levels.

 

Option D. Nesiritide: Nesiritide is a synthetic brain natriuretic peptide (BNP), acts as a natriuretic and vasodilator. Primarily used in acute decompensated heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Omapatrilat inhibits both neprilysin and angiotensin-converting enzyme, thereby decreasing angiotensin II and increasing natriuretic peptides, promoting natriuresis, diuresis, and vasodilation.

questions.text: A man presents with a history of dysuria and urethral discharge after having unprotected sexual intercourse. Gram-staining of the purulent discharge is seen in the following image. What is the treatment of choice for this infection? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ceftriaxone

 

The symptoms with the microscopic findings which shows gram-negative intracellular diplococci suggests infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae. The treatment of choice for the infection is ceftriaxone.

 

Treatment of Gonorrhoea –

 

  • Third generation cephalosporins – DOC for uncomplicated gonococcal infection - both the sexual partners should be treated.
  • Ceftriaxone (250 mg given IM, single dose)
  • Cefixime (400 mg given orally, single dose)
  • If coexisting chlamydial infection – azithromycin or doxycycline added.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Erythromycin and Option B. Azithromycin are macrolides, generally used for chlamydial infections or as a co-treatment when chlamydia is suspected alongside gonorrhea.

 

Option D. Penicillin G is no longer recommended as the primary treatment for gonorrhea due to widespread resistance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For uncomplicated gonorrhea, especially cases presenting with urethral discharge and identified intracellular gram-negative diplococci, Ceftriaxone remains the treatment of choice. This choice reflects current guidelines that prioritize efficacy and resistance profiles in managing sexually transmitted infections.

questions.text: Identify the finding shown in the image below: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Herpes labialis

 

Explanation:

 

  • Herpes labialis, also known as a cold sore, is characterized by clusters of numerous grouped vesicles around the lips.
  • Recurrent herpetic lesions are very common & are vesicular and ulcerative and tend to occur in the same region.
  • Herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1) commonly and type 2 (HSV-2) rarely are responsible for its occurrence

 

Treatment: Foscarnet or cidofovir if acyclovir resistance develops in a patient with recurrent Herpes labialis. They act on viral DNA polymerases thus blocking DNA replication.

  • Oral acyclovir 200 mg and 5% topical acyclovir.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Herpangina or vesicular pharyngitis:

 

  • It is characterized by the presence of ulcerating small vesicles on the oral fauces and the posterior pharyngeal wall as seen in the below image.

 

 

  • Causative agent: Coxsackie virus. 

 

Option B. Molluscum contagiosum: Pearly white, wart-like umbilicated papules seen due to infection by Pox virus.

 

 

 

Option C. Impetigo: It is of 2 types:

 

  • Bullous – S. aureus
  • Non-bullous – S. aureus and Streptococcus. Golden-yellow or honey coloured crust seen.
     

 

Educational Objective:

 

Herpes labialis is identified as condition characterized by recurrent clusters of vesicles on the lips, caused by the herpes simplex virus, and distinguish it from other vesicular or pustular lesions such as herpangina, molluscum contagiosum, and impetigo.

 

References

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I, Chapter 25 Page no 25.12, 25.17-19, 25.20

Fitzpatrick’s Dermatology 9th edition Page no 2721
